label: Public Safety
description: The paramount obligation of engineers to prioritize the safety, health, and welfare of the general public above all other considerations in their professional work.
text_references: Hold paramount the safety, health, and welfare of the public.
Engineers shall hold paramount the safety, health, and welfare of the public.
Notify employer or client and appropriate authority if judgment is overruled endangering life/property.

label: Professional Competence
description: The obligation of engineers to only perform services in areas where they possess adequate knowledge, skills, and expertise to ensure quality and safety.
text_references: Perform services only in areas of their competence.
Accept only qualified assignments.
Do not sign off on work outside area of expertise.
Commit to ongoing professional development.

label: Truthfulness
description: The ethical requirement for engineers to communicate honestly and objectively in all professional statements, avoiding misrepresentation or deception.
text_references: Issue public statements only in an objective and truthful manner.
Be objective and include all pertinent facts in statements or testimony.
Express opinions based on facts and competence.
Engineers shall avoid conduct that deceives the public.

label: Fidelity to Employers and Clients
description: The duty of engineers to act as faithful agents or trustees for their employers or clients, maintaining loyalty and acting in their best interests while balancing other ethical obligations.
text_references: Act for each employer or client as faithful agents or trustees.
Do not disclose client/employer information without consent or legal obligation.
Disclose actual or potential conflicts of interest.
Do not accept gifts or considerations from outside agents.

label: Integrity
description: The fundamental character trait requiring engineers to adhere to high moral and ethical standards in all professional activities, including honesty, consistency, and moral uprightness.
text_references: Engineers are expected to exhibit the highest standards of honesty and integrity.
Engineers shall be guided by honesty and integrity.
Uphold professional dignity.
Conduct themselves honorably, responsibly, ethically, and lawfully so as to enhance the honor, reputation, and usefulness of the profession.

label: Conflict of Interest
description: Situations where an engineer's personal interests, relationships, or influences could compromise professional judgment or obligations to employers, clients, or the public.
text_references: Disclose actual or potential conflicts of interest.
Accept multiple compensations only with full disclosure.
Avoid decision-making in public positions involving own interests.
Engineers shall not be influenced by conflicting interests.

label: Confidentiality
description: The obligation to protect and not disclose private or proprietary information obtained during professional service without proper authorization.
text_references: Do not disclose client/employer information without consent or legal obligation.
Engineers shall maintain confidentiality.
Do not share confidential information without consent.
Avoid conflicts in new employment with specialized knowledge.

label: Public
description: The general population whose safety, health, and welfare engineers must prioritize in their professional work, representing the broader societal stakeholders affected by engineering decisions.
text_references: Hold paramount the safety, health, and welfare of the public.
Engineering has a direct and vital impact on the quality of life for all people.
Engineers shall strive to serve the public interest.
Promote public understanding of engineering.

label: Employers and Clients
description: Organizations or individuals who engage engineers' professional services and to whom engineers owe duties of loyalty, competence, and faithful service.
text_references: Act for each employer or client as faithful agents or trustees.
Warn employers or clients of project issues.
Notify employer before accepting outside work.
Respect employer policies in outside work.

label: Professional Colleagues
description: Other engineers and professionals with whom engineers interact, collaborate, or whose work they may review or evaluate.
text_references: Engineers shall not harm others' professional reputation.
Do not review another engineer's work without disclosure.
Do not mislead to attract other engineers.
Name individuals responsible for work when possible.

label: Accountability
description: The principle that engineers must take responsibility for their professional actions and decisions, including acknowledging errors and accepting consequences.
text_references: Engineers shall accept responsibility for their actions.
Admit and correct errors.
Follow registration laws.
Avoid unethical acts under corporate cover.

label: Fairness and Equity
description: The commitment to treat all individuals justly, without discrimination or bias, and to ensure equitable distribution of benefits and burdens in engineering practice.
text_references: The services provided by engineers require honesty, impartiality, fairness, and equity.
Treat all individuals with fairness and respect.
Do not offer bribes or commissions to secure contracts.
Reject inducements from suppliers.

label: Sustainability
description: The consideration of long-term environmental, social, and economic impacts in engineering decisions to meet present needs without compromising future generations.
text_references: Support sustainability.

label: Professional Development
description: The ongoing process of maintaining and improving professional knowledge, skills, and competence throughout an engineer's career.
text_references: Commit to ongoing professional development.

label: Public Education
description: The responsibility of engineers to promote public understanding of engineering principles, practices, and impacts to enable informed civic participation.
text_references: Engage in civic and educational outreach.
Promote public understanding of engineering.

label: Intellectual Property
description: The recognition and protection of rights related to creative works, designs, and innovations in engineering, including proper attribution and respect for proprietary information.
text_references: Engineers shall credit others appropriately.
Name individuals responsible for work when possible.
Respect proprietary rights of clients.
Set ownership expectations clearly.

label: Professional Reputation
description: The collective perception of the engineering profession's integrity, competence, and value to society, which individual engineers have a duty to uphold and enhance.
text_references: Conduct themselves honorably, responsibly, ethically, and lawfully so as to enhance the honor, reputation, and usefulness of the profession.
Uphold professional dignity.
Engineers shall not harm others' professional reputation.

label: Compliance with Standards
description: The obligation to adhere to established technical standards, codes, and regulations that govern engineering practice to ensure safety and quality.
text_references: Approve only engineering documents conforming to standards.
Report known code violations to professional or public bodies.
Refuse to sign non-compliant documents and report pressure.

label: Whistleblowing
description: The ethical duty to report violations, unsafe conditions, or unethical practices to appropriate authorities when normal channels have failed to address the issue.
text_references: Notify employer or client and appropriate authority if judgment is overruled endangering life/property.
Report known code violations to professional or public bodies.
Refuse to sign non-compliant documents and report pressure.

label: Avoidance of Deception
description: The ethical requirement to refrain from any form of dishonesty, misrepresentation, or misleading conduct in professional activities.
text_references: Avoid deceptive acts.
Do not misrepresent qualifications or responsibilities.
Engineers shall avoid conduct that deceives the public.
Avoid material misrepresentations or omissions.
